quizzes.title: Science Quiz: Models and Monument
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, lombarda, committee. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Rubles are used in which Eastern European country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Russia

questions.question: What is the official currency of the European Union?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Euro

questions.question: Which country uses the yen as its national currency?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Japan

questions.question: On March 9, 1841the Supreme Court upheld a lower court decision which ruled that Joseph Cinque and other members of the Mende people had been illegally enslaved and were ordered to be returned to Africa. What replica sails the seas and visits ports as an educational tool and ambassador of goodwill?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Amistad

questions.question: Which model of car, first released by Lotus in 1996, has a hand-finished fibreglass shell bonded to an extruded aluminium frame, is capable of speeds up to 150 mph (240 km/h) and at the time of its release weighed just over half of what a Porsche Boxter did?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elise

questions.question: What German auto manufacturer was originally set up in 1910 and has a slogan in its home country which translates as Advancement Through Technology?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Audi

questions.question: What luxury car brand was resurrected in 2002 by Mercedes-Benz?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maybach

questions.question: The committee required four criteria for submission to design this monument: The monument must harmonize with the surroundings, the monument will not make any political statement, it will honor service and must include the 57,661 names of those killed or missing in action. On what memorial will you find these lines, The names of those who gave their lives and of those who remain missing are inscribed in the order they were taken from us.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vietnam Veterans Memorial

questions.question: Founded in 1899 by three brothers, this French vehicle company has produced models called Voiturette 1CV and Dauphine, but generally numbers its models. The company was first to patent the sedan car and the turbocharger.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Renault

questions.question: The East Gate is inscribed with the time 9:01 A.M. and the West Gate with 9:03 A. M. In what city would you find 168 chairs in the Field of Empty Chairs?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oklahoma City, OK

questions.question: Name Nissans luxury car brand in the American, Canadian, Mexican, Middle Eastern, South Korean and Taiwanese markets. Models include G37, M, EX35 and QX56.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Infiniti

questions.question: This company which produces automobiles, motorbikes and wheelchairs was founded in 1909. Models of cars include Jimny and Grand Vitara.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Suzuki

questions.question: Richmond, Virginia was once the capitol of the Confederacy and in this city  you will find what is now known as Monument Avenue. Monument Avenue was known as Confederate Avenue when the first statute, of General Robert E. Lee, was erected in 1890. As a sign of changing times, whose statute was unveiled in 1996?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arthur Ashe

questions.question: This Italian motor company, originally called Anonima Lombarda Fabbrica Automobili, was founded in 1910 and was acquired by Fiat in 1986.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alfa Romeo

questions.question: This memorial is located on 7.5 acres of land and is made up of four rooms or courtyards. In room two, you will find these words inscribed I see one-third of a nation ill-housed, ill-clad and ill-nourished. The test of our progress is not whether we add more to the abundance of those who have much; it is whether we provide enough for those who have little. Whose carved figure would you see next to his little dog, Fala?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Franklin Delano Roosevelt

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Countries and Euro
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, country, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which ancient empire used the denarius?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roman Empire

questions.question: Jumeirah Beach Hotel, one of Dubais most luxurious hotels, has a unique architectural structure, resembling what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A wave

questions.question: Which of these countries does not use the peso as its national currency?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Venezuela

questions.question: Which of these countries used the lira before it switched to the euro?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italy

questions.question: A small part of Russia lies just north of Poland on the Baltic Sea, separated from the rest of Russia by three nations. What is the current name of this exclave of Russia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kaliningrad

questions.question: Which 102-storey Art Deco style building was officially opened in May, 1931?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Empire State Building

questions.question: Before switching to the euro, which of these countries used francs?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: France

questions.question: Which of these countries use dollars?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Canada and Australia

questions.question: Before it started using the euro, which country used marks?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Germany

questions.question: This hotel located in the capital of the small African country of Rwanda is not only famous for its luxury, but also for the nearly 1,000 people it saved during the Rwandan Genocide in 1994.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hôtel des Mille Collines

questions.question: This British hotel, located on Strand street in London and famous for its superb cooking, carries the name of the palace which once occupied the site.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Savoy Palace

questions.question: Which of the following countries uses the pound as its currency?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: United Kingdom

questions.question: This nation, which became independent in 2002, shares an island with Indonesia. Part of its territory, the district of Oecussi-Ambeno, is separated from the rest of the country by a part of the Indonesian province of East Nusa Tenggara.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: East Timor

questions.question: If you long for a Caribbean adventure, this Las Vegas hotel resort carrying the name of a Robert Louis Stevensons famous book, is the right place for you.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Treasure Island

questions.question: As unbelievable as it may seem, seventeen of the worlds twenty largest hotels are located in the same city, on the same street. Which is this city?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Las Vegas

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Country and Nation
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, reunification, decreed. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The exclave of Cabinda in Africa is separated from the rest of the country it is part of by the Atlantic coastal portion of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. What nation does Cabinda belong to?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Angola

questions.question: This Roman god, usually depicted with two faces looking away from each other, gives the name of one of the months of the year and is a symbol of change and transition.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Janus

questions.question: The towns of Ceuta and Melilla in northern Morocco are autonomous cities of what nation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spain

questions.question: The Scottish New Year celebration, whereupon people traditionally sing ‘Auld Lang Syne’, is called what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hogmanay

questions.question: Name the mythical figure, depicted as an old bearded man, dressed in a robe and usually carrying a scythe and an hourglass.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Father Time

questions.question: In this country, the new year begins between January 21 and February 21, at new moon.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: China

questions.question: Each year, on January 1, a New Year concert takes place, presenting mostly music of the Strauss family, broadcast in over 40 countries. In which city does this concert take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vienna

questions.question: This town was a South African enclave, surrounded on three sides by the nation of Namibia (and by the Atlantic Ocean on the other side) until it was ceded to Namibia in 1994.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walvis Bay

questions.question: Nakhichevan is an landlocked exclave, bordered by Armenia, Iran and Turkey. What nation is it a part of?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Azerbaijan

questions.question: The peninsula of Point Roberts, an exclave USA, can only be reached by land from other parts of its state by passing through the Canadian province of British Columbia. What U.S. state does Point Roberts belong to?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Washington

questions.question: According to which calendar, decreed in 1582, does the new year begin on January 1?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gregorian

questions.question: This English Poet Laureate, regarded as the chief representative of the Victorian age poetry, wrote the poem, ‘The Death of the Old Year’.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alfred Tennyson

questions.question: The Musandam peninsula on the southern side of the entrance to the Persian Gulf is an exclave of what country, separated from the rest of the country by the United Arab Emirates?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oman

questions.question: This popular annual parade, which originated in 1890, takes place on New Year’s Day in Pasadena, California.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tournament of Roses

questions.question: Until the reunification of Germany in 1990, this city was a West German enclave, completely surrounded by East Germany.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: West Berlin

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Person and Laws
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, country, death. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This legal Latin term, which in English means obvious, denotes evidence that is sufficient to prove a particular fact.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: prima facie

questions.question: In the judicial system of England and Wales this court has two divisions - Civil Division and Criminal Division.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Court of Appeal

questions.question: This American novelist, author of ‘Life on Mississippi’, made the following humorous remark: ‘New Year’s Day - now is the accepted time to make your regular annual good resolutions. Next week you can begin paving hell with them as usual.’
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark Twain

questions.question: Who had the dubious honor of being Alcatrazs very first inmate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Frank Bolt

questions.question: On May 17, 1954 this person announced the decision of the Supreme Court regarding Brown v. Board of Education, a landmark case in the United States legal history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chief Justice Earl Warren

questions.question: When did the US Air Force officially become activated?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: September 18, 1947

questions.question: Which treaty, signed on 7 February, 1992, led to the creation of the European Union?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maastricht Treaty

questions.question: In this country, New Year, called ‘oshogatsu’, is generally regarded as the most important public holiday. Homes and entrance gates are decorated with ornaments made of pine, bamboo and plum trees.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Japan

questions.question: This collection of laws, originating from Mesopotamia, is known as one of the earliest sets of laws.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Code of Hammurabi

questions.question: This ancient legislation, which stood at the foundation of the Roman law, marked the beginning of the Roman legal history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lex Duodecim Tabularum

questions.question: The United Nations Convention on the Right of the Child, which sets out the civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights of children, was adopted by The United Nations General Assembly on what date?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: November 20, 1989

questions.question: Before becoming a separate entity, the US Air Force existed under this name.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: US Army Air Force

questions.question: This person presided over the Federal Constitutional Court of Germany from 1987 to 1994, before being elected President of Germany.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roman Herzog

questions.question: The death penalty was abolished in Northern Ireland under the Northern Ireland (Emergency Powers) Act in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1973

questions.question: Clara Shortidge Foltz was the first woman to be admitted to practice law in the State of California. This happened in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1878

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Pyramid and Monument
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, egypt, squadron. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Dutch were those who brought the Christmas tree tradition to the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What was the nickname given to the group of Black pilots in WW II that excelled in aerial combat?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tuskegee Airmen

questions.question: In Ukraine spiders and spider webs are a traditional part of Christmas decorations.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In Victorian England the Christmas turkeys wore boots as they were walked into London.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This monument was built in ancient Egypt, had many rooms and a fantastic maze hidden in a pyramid. Its walls were covered with gigantic figures. It is not certain when exactly it was destroyed, but during Roman times it was repeatedly plundered due to its fine stone.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Egyptian labyrinth

questions.question: As the song states, Christmas was once a 12-day celebration.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Connecticut was the first U.S. state to recognize Christmas as an official holiday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: A traditional early English Christmas dinner was a pigs head with mustard.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The USAF Air Demonstration Squadron are also known as this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thunderbirds

questions.question: We can trace the origins of the first Christmas card back to 1843.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This massive step pyramid (about 210 by 150 feet in size) is the most well-preserved monument from the age of the Sumerians. In the 4th century BC the river Euphrates changed its course and the city, in which this pyramid was built, was abandoned.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Ziggurat at Ur

questions.question: The common Christmas plant Poinsettias is poisonous to humans.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: On what date did the Korean War begin and when did it end?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: June 25, 1950 - July 27, 1953

questions.question: The first use of electric Christmas lights was in the 1920s.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: The traditional hook-like red-white candy canes started out as straight white sticks.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Temples and President
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, structure, presidency. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: These temples were built on the islands of Malta and Gozo earlier than the Egyptian pyramids and Stonehenge. They date from the Bronze Age - 3,600 BC.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ggantija and the Megalithic Temples

questions.question: Who was the first US president with no natural children?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Washington

questions.question: These buildings were designed to be both tombs and temples.  Mayan royalties carried out self-torture and mutilation rites on the roofs, as they believed that blood nourished gods.

options.text: Ggantija and the Megalithic Temples on Malta

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Mayan Pyramids

questions.question: This was the monumental marble tomb of the Anatolian king Mausolus. 140 feet high, it rivalled even the Egyptian pyramids.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Mausoleum

questions.question: Who actually built Monticello, the estate of Thomas Jefferson?

options.text: Jefferson built it with his own two hands.
Masons brought over from Europe by Jefferson

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jeffersons slaves

questions.question: Who was the first US President to be born in the 19th century?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Millard Fillmore

questions.question: Who was the first incumbent, one-term President not to be even nominated for another term although he wanted the office?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Millard Fillmore

questions.question: This very important Supreme Court case struck down a Connecticut law banning the use of contraceptives.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Griswold v. Connecticut

questions.question: This building inspired the Biblical myth of the Tower of Babel. It was a gigantic seven-stage multicolored pyramidal tower, over 300 feet high. However, only the ground plan and traces of the three stairs leading up to it have been preserved.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Ziggurat of Marduk

questions.question: When George Washington first won the Presidency, how many states did he carry?

options.text: None - he was appointed, not voted in
10 - he did not carry three states

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 10 - he did not carry three states

questions.question: This is one of the few surviving relics of the Phrygian culture, which occupied the territory known today as Anatolia. The relic was used for religious ceremonies. It is generally considered that the reasons for its semi-destruction were major climatic cataclysms.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Midas Monument

questions.question: This First Lady of the United States started the first White House library.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abigail Fillmore

questions.question: It was the most famous artistic work of ancient Greece. The statue was made of gold and ivory and presided over the Olympic games. The games were forbidden, accused of being pagan in the 5th century by Emperor Theodosius I. Later, the statue disappeared and its fate has been unknown since.

options.text: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia
The Colossus of Helios at Rhodes

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia

questions.question: This ancient-Greek structure had a single path running to and from the center, in 7 concentric rings. It was burned to the ground in the 15th century.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Labyrinth at Knossos

questions.question: This great marble temple was built in Ephesus. It is famous for being one of the biggest temples the ancient Greeks ever built.  It was burned by a madman, who wanted to immortalize his name.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Temple of Artemis
